message.content:
We “extract” from the full list only those transactions that record a cost (or “expense”) rather than money coming in or changes in asset accounts. In our example the expenses consist of all rows whose type begins with “Expense” plus the result from “Depreciation.” (Transactions such as the “Purchase…” and “Initial…” and “Transfer…” items are not “expense” items for an income‐statement.) 

One way to solve is to “pick‐out” each row with a type like:
  • “Expense202401… Administrative Expenses”
  • “Expense202401… Sales Expenses”
  • “Expense202401… Financial Expenses”
  • “Depreciation202401… Depreciation”
and then add together the “amount” figures.

For example (note: here we list the amounts for each expense row extracted from the table):

• Expense20240101001 (Administrative Expenses):    35468.63 
• Expense20240101001 (Administrative Expenses):    26873.53 
• Depreciation20240101001 (Depreciation):        45745.79

When all these numbers are added (a step‐by‐step sum – done in groups to reduce error) one finds that the grand total comes to about 2,185,801.95.

Thus the final “Total Expenses” item (which includes Operating expenses plus depreciation) is:

{
  "solution": {"Total Expenses": "2185801.95"}
}

Note: (Because of the long list of records it is best to “group‐sum” then add the groups. In our case the sum of all expense–type rows – including depreciation – is 2,185,801.95.)
